configuration.courseTitle: Assessment and Treatment of Trauma Precourse Module

resource.narrationText: Welcome to Module 1: Mechanism of Trauma.

Understanding the physics that underlie the mechanism of injury helps the EMS responder to focus his or her examination of the patient. Understanding energy transfer can raise the index of suspicion for hidden injuries. Knowledge of the mechanism of injury may also help the responder anticipate the severity of injuries and decide which cases need minimal scene time and a rapid transport and when slower and safer transport is more appropriate.
xxx
Trauma is defined as an injury or wound to the body by an external agent, force, or mechanism.

Energy is the ability to do work. We can further define energy based on its different forms—for example, mechanical, chemical, thermal, electrical, and barometric. Mechanical energy is the force given off by movement on a macro level, such as the deformation of metal when a motor vehicle hits a tree. Chemical energy is the energy contained in the bonds between molecules; it is released when the atoms or molecules react with other chemicals. Thermal energy is measured by temperature and is also related to the release of energy stored in chemical bonds. Electrical energy is transferred by electrons traveling from one ion to another. Barometric energy is a change in the pressure of a gas, including the atmosphere itself.

Energy can be further classified as kinetic energy (the energy used during movement) or potential energy (energy that is being stored). The amount of energy in movement (kinetic) can be calculated by multiplying the weight (mass) of an object that is moving times the speed (velocity) squared and dividing that number in half. Energy dissipation is the process by which KE is transformed into another form of energy, such as thermal, electrical, chemical, or mechanical. Protective devices (eg, seatbelts, airbags) manipulate the way that energy is dissipated into an injury. A seatbelt converts the kinetic energy of the occupant into a seatbelt-to-body pressure force rather than into a steering wheel deformation against the torso or a windshield shattering against the head.

Basic Newtonian physics explains energy relationships through three laws. We can apply these laws to help understand how kinetic energy causes trauma. Newton’s first law explains that when an automobile is in motion, it stays in motion until it hits a bridge abutment. The driver of that car stays in motion until he or she hits the steering wheel. The driver’s organs continue to move until they hit the inside of the body that has already stopped. Newton’s second law explains that the amount of force to be transferred depends on the distance an object takes to stop. (In physics, acceleration and deceleration are the same thing.) A body landing on soft earth and grass with a longer stopping distance results in less energy transfer than one landing on concrete with its lack of deformation and shorter stopping distance.
The application of Newton’s laws can help the EMS responder determine how much energy may have been transferred into the body. Knowledge of anatomy will help determine which organs may be affected.

Trauma is usually classified into two categories: blunt and penetrating. Blunt trauma involves the spread of energy over an area of the body, usually without breaking the skin. Because the body is soft, the energy is transmitted through the body wall to the organs within. Penetrating trauma involves energy that is concentrated enough at one point to break the skin. Penetrating trauma is visually dramatic, but blunt trauma may cause more internal damage without offering visible clues to the EMS provider doing an assessment.

Automobile collisions demonstrate the principles of energy transfer. The five types of automobile collisions tend to produce specific patterns of injuries and give the responder an idea where to focus his or her examination.

In a motor vehicle collision, three types of collisions occur. Two of them are visible (car strikes object, person strikes inside of car), but it is the third and unseen one (internal organs strike the outer body) that most concerns EMS personnel. This is a direct application of the Newtonian law that states a body in motion stays in motion and a body at rest stays at rest.

With a head-on collision, the greater the damage to the front of the vehicle, the greater the energy that needs to be absorbed. In a head-on collision, the direction in which an unrestrained body travels depends on the angle of the seat and the type of motor vehicle. The patient who travels up and over, hitting the windshield, may suffer head, neck, chest, and upper abdominal injuries. The down-and-under pathway may result in knee fractures, knee dislocation, fractures of the femur, dislocation of the hip, and fracture of the pelvis. In some cases, lower abdominal injuries may occur from hitting the steering wheel.

The vehicle that is rear ended is another example of a body at rest staying at rest: The vehicle and the seat attached to it are pushed forward, pushing the patient’s torso forward. If the head restraint is not adjusted to be equal to the top of the head, the patient’s head remains at rest and snaps backward as the body is pushed out from underneath, injuring the neck. At low speed, this can cause ligamentous injury (whiplash); at higher speed, it can cause a cervical fracture. In high-speed collisions, the entire seat may be torn from the mounting bracket. The target vehicle (the one that is hit) may then continue to travel forward and suffer a secondary front-end or lateral collision.

Lateral collisions are also called T-bone collisions. The passengers closest to the point of impact will have received the greatest amount of energy and should be examined closely for injury. Seatbelts and side-impact air bags reduce lateral-impact injuries by moving the patient in the same direction as the car is pushed. Typical T-bone collision injuries include fractures of the clavicle; lateral wall rib fractures, including possible flail chest and injury to underlying organs; and pelvic and hip fractures. The head can be thrown back into the B post; due to the pivot point of head on the neck and the center of gravity of the head, rotational injury to the neck can be severe. The unrestrained vehicle occupant may be thrown across the vehicle, suffering injury on the opposite side of the body or causing injury to another occupant.

As in a T-bone collision, in a rotational collision the most energy is transferred closest to the point of impact. Thus, passengers closest to the point of impact will have received the most energy and should be treated with the highest index of suspicion. Rotational injuries may also occur when body parts are whipped around.

An unrestrained occupant in a rollover collision may be thrown around the vehicle in unpredictable ways and suffer multiple injuries. Even the restrained passenger may suffer torn organs due to the violent shearing forces in these collisions. The unrestrained occupant is at even greater risk. An ejected passenger has a 25-fold greater risk of death compared to one who stays inside the vehicle. One in three ejected patients has a spinal fracture. Partial ejections may lead to extremities being crushed under the vehicle.

In motorcycle collisions, the same laws of physics apply as in motor vehicle collisions. In a head-on collision, the rider travels over the handlebars, which often results in bilateral femur fractures, followed by injury to the head or whichever part of the body the rider lands on. In angular collisions, lower-extremity fractures to the side of the rider caught between the motorcycle and the second vehicle are often complicated by burns from the exhaust pipes. If the rider “lays” the bike down to avoid a collision, then full-thickness abrasions are possible if the rider is not wearing fully protective clothing. In addition, because the rider will be moving at the velocity at which the bike was traveling, if the rider skidding along the ground strikes something, such as a curbing, then significant injury may occur.

Pedestrian-versus-automobile collisions result in a three-collision pattern that is somewhat determined by the age of the pedestrian. Adults tend to be hit by the bumper in the lower legs, be thrown up on to the windshield, fall off the vehicle (often head first, causing spinal injury), and hit the ground. Children tend to be hit in the chest, both because of their size and because they turn toward the vehicle; they are then hit by the hood or bumper, which is still traveling forward, and finally are run over or dragged under the vehicle because they are not thrown clear.

With falls, the height of the fall and the surface on which the patient lands are the most important factors in determining the severity of injury. Falls from greater than three times body height should be assumed to involve serious injury. How the patient lands is also associated with certain injury patterns. Landing on the feet transmits force up the legs to the pelvis and spine; as the patient pitches forward, fractures to the wrists and the shoulder may occur.

Each type of sport has its own characteristic injury patterns. EMS providers responding to sports injuries may do well to consult trainers, ski patrollers, or others at the scene to help understand the forces involved. Evaluating damage to any equipment involved may also give clues to the forces involved. The same laws of physics apply as in a motor vehicle collision.

In trauma due to violence, the injuries depend on the speed of the weapon used. Kinetic energy still equals ½ mass x acceleration<FONT FACE="FranFontSuperscript">2</FONT>. Fists and knives travel at low speeds; handgun and long-gun projectiles travel at higher speeds. The cross-section of the object striking the patient also determines how the energy is transferred.

As the velocity (speed) of the object increases, so does the amount of energy transferred. Low-velocity objects have less energy and transfer only the energy of their edge and length. By comparison, medium- and high-velocity objects have much greater kinetic energy. The energy creates a temporary cavity away from the direct path of the projectile (called cavitation), with many micro tears occurring in the tissues; a permanent cavity also occurs along the path of travel of the projectile. The damage from cavitation may extend as much as 10 times the diameter of the entrance wound for high-velocity wounds.

The damage from stab wounds is limited to the length of the blade; this factor, plus the strength of the attacker, determines the depth of penetration. The gender of the attacker may help determine the angle of penetration: Women are known to slash in a downward angle, whereas men stab upward. Multiple wounds mean multiple injuries.
The severity of gunshot wounds varies widely. With shotgun blasts, the most important factor is the distance between the weapon and the patient.

Explosions can be accidental, such as occurs in an industrial accident or a natural gas explosion, or they can be the result of purposeful violence. Five types of injury are attributed to explosions. The first injury pattern results from the atmospheric overpressure wave, which causes damage primarily to air-filled organs, such as the lungs and intestines. Secondary injuries occur when shrapnel is sent flying, causing penetrating wounds. Tertiary injuries arise when the patient is sent flying, much like a fall from a height or a pedestrian struck by a motor vehicle. Injuries from heat (burns) or poisoning from fumes are called quaternary injuries. Quaternary injuries are associated with biological contamination from pieces of flying debris.
These factors can change the outcome of blasts. For example, intervening structures can deflect the explosive forces, and greater distance from the epicenter can lead to less severe injury.

The overpressure wave can cause internal injury that is associated with very few external signs. Pulmonary injuries, sometimes called “blast lung,” are the most common cause of death. Because the onset of some of these injuries may be delayed, a close watch should be kept over patients who have been exposed to blasts. Signs of deterioration include oxygen desaturation, pulmonary edema, and respiratory distress.

Application of the principles of physics in conjunction with a knowledge of anatomy can help the EMS responder have a high index of suspicion for hidden injury. Actively looking for and finding these hidden injuries can lead to lifesaving care for traumatized patients.
